meta.content: Facile Synthesis of a Carbon-Encapsulated Pd Catalyst for Oxygen Reduction Reaction in Proton Exchange Membrane Fuel Cells
meta.name: dc.title

meta.content: Electrocatalysis 2019 11:1
meta.name: dc.source

meta.content: 2019 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC, part of Springer Nature
meta.name: dc.copyright

meta.content: The key to popularizing proton exchange fuel cells is developing highly active, stable, and cost-effective catalysts for oxygen reduction reaction. Pd is considered as an alternative to Pt due to its high tolerance to poisoning and electronic similarity with Pt, which is a robust but expensive catalyst. However, its vulnerability to dissolving in acidic media prevents the use of Pd as an oxygen reduction reaction catalyst. In this study, a facile synthesis method was developed to prepare a carbon-encapsulated Pd catalyst using aniline. The oxidative polymerization of aniline with a Pd precursor formed Pd nanoparticles embedded in a rod-shaped polyaniline matrix. The polyaniline matrix was carbonized using heat treatment, which then acted as a source of N-containing carbon layer that protects Pd nanoparticles from dissolution and improves oxygen reduction reaction activity. The stability and oxygen reduction reaction activity of the synthesized Pd catalyst were strongly dependent on the heat treatment temperature. The Pd catalysts heat-treated at 300 °C and 500 °C exhibited improved activity and stability as compared to commercial Pd/C. We envision that this method is suitable for mass production of active and stable oxygen reduction reaction catalysts in proton exchange fuel cells.

meta.content: Facile Synthesis of a Carbon-Encapsulated Pd Catalyst for Oxygen Reduction Reaction in Proton Exchange Membrane Fuel Cells - Electrocatalysis

The key to popularizing proton exchange fuel cells is developing highly active, stable, and cost-effective catalysts for oxygen reduction reaction. Pd is considered as an alternative to Pt due to its high tolerance to poisoning and electronic similarity with Pt, which is a robust but expensive catalyst. However, its vulnerability to dissolving in acidic media prevents the use of Pd as an oxygen reduction reaction catalyst. In this study, a facile synthesis method was developed to prepare a carbon-encapsulated Pd catalyst using aniline. The oxidative polymerization of aniline with a Pd precursor formed Pd nanoparticles embedded in a rod-shaped polyaniline matrix. The polyaniline matrix was carbonized using heat treatment, which then acted as a source of N-containing carbon layer that protects Pd nanoparticles from dissolution and improves oxygen reduction reaction activity. The stability and oxygen reduction reaction activity of the synthesized Pd catalyst were strongly dependent on the heat treatment temperature. The Pd catalysts heat-treated at 300 °C and 500 °C exhibited improved activity and stability as compared to commercial Pd/C. We envision that this method is suitable for mass production of active and stable oxygen reduction reaction catalysts in proton exchange fuel cells.

div.div: Facile Synthesis of a Carbon-Encapsulated Pd Catalyst for Oxygen Reduction Reaction in Proton Exchange Membrane Fuel Cells

header.h1: Facile Synthesis of a Carbon-Encapsulated Pd Catalyst for Oxygen Reduction Reaction in Proton Exchange Membrane Fuel Cells
header.p:
Electrocatalysis
volume
11
,
pages
77–85 (
2020
)
Cite this article

353
Accesses

div.p: The key to popularizing proton exchange fuel cells is developing highly active, stable, and cost-effective catalysts for oxygen reduction reaction. Pd is considered as an alternative to Pt due to its high tolerance to poisoning and electronic similarity with Pt, which is a robust but expensive catalyst. However, its vulnerability to dissolving in acidic media prevents the use of Pd as an oxygen reduction reaction catalyst. In this study, a facile synthesis method was developed to prepare a carbon-encapsulated Pd catalyst using aniline. The oxidative polymerization of aniline with a Pd precursor formed Pd nanoparticles embedded in a rod-shaped polyaniline matrix. The polyaniline matrix was carbonized using heat treatment, which then acted as a source of N-containing carbon layer that protects Pd nanoparticles from dissolution and improves oxygen reduction reaction activity. The stability and oxygen reduction reaction activity of the synthesized Pd catalyst were strongly dependent on the heat treatment temperature. The Pd catalysts heat-treated at 300 °C and 500 °C exhibited improved activity and stability as compared to commercial Pd/C. We envision that this method is suitable for mass production of active and stable oxygen reduction reaction catalysts in proton exchange fuel cells.
Schematic diagram showing a synthesis process and the HR-TEM image of Pd nanoparticle encapsulated by carbon shell

Fuel cells have great potential as energy systems due to their high energy conversion efficiency and eco-friendliness [
1
]. Fuel cells are classified according to the fuels and electrolytes used. The proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs), which utilize a polymer membrane that permeates protons, have attracted considerable attention as a power system for vehicles. A PEMFC possesses a high energy density which allows a long operating life and compact design. A low operating temperature and quick startup are added advantages. However, PEMFCs are not yet viable as compared to other power system technologies, like internal combustion engines and advanced batteries. For PEMFCs to be commercially viable, they must meet performance and durability requirements that are comparable to existing power systems along with being cost-effective. One of the hurdles to achieving cost-effectiveness is the use of an expensive Pt catalyst as a cathode material. The oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is a sluggish cathode reaction occurring in a PEMFC, and Pt is the most effective catalyst for this reaction [
2
,
3
]. However, its limited availability and high cost have encouraged extensive research on alternatives to Pt-based catalysts [
4
]. The ultimate goal is the development of nonprecious catalytic materials like doped carbon and transition metal-based catalysts that show comparable catalytic activity and stability to Pt [
5
,
6
,
7
]. However, the catalytic activities toward ORR of the reported nonprecious catalysts are still low, and their stability has not yet been verified.

A relatively abundant and less expensive Pd has also been extensively studied as an alternative to Pt due to its similarity to Pt in electronic configuration and chemical properties, in addition to its robustness against poisoning [
8
,
9
]. Despite the fact that Pd is expected to exhibit high ORR activity in density functional theory (DFT) calculations, its actual activity is significantly lower than Pt since Pd is oxidized at lesser positive potentials [
10
,
11
,
12
]. In addition, nanoparticulate Pd, which is the most common form of the Pd catalyst, is vulnerable to coarsening and dissolution in acidic media, which lead to electrochemical activity loss in PEMFC operations [
13
]. Hence, a majority of the studies focus on the use of Pd as a co-material to other metals, including Pt, to improve electrocatalytic activity and stability as well as reduce costs [
14
,
15
,
16
]. Efforts to improve the ORR activity and stability of Pd catalysts, however, are still under way. Xiao et al. demonstrated that Pd nanorods can exhibit ORR activity that is comparable to bulk Pt activity by controlling the surface crystalline structure of Pd [
17
]. Yang et al. synthesized a Pd/nanoporous carbon support and achieved higher ORR activity and stability levels [
18
]. The Pd particle size effect on the stability of Pd/C toward voltage cycling was investigated by Mittermeier et al. to show that larger Pd particles are more tolerant to coarsening and dissolution than smaller ones [
19
]. It was also reported by Cai and co-workers that incorporating a light metalloid element like B to the interstices of the Pd lattice improves ORR activity by downshifting the Pd d-band center [
20
].

Recently, the encapsulation of individual nanoparticle catalysts with porous materials has been focused for achieving high electrochemical activity as well as stability in PEMFCs. Porous materials like carbon and silica, which are electrochemically stable, protect nanocatalysts from coarsening and dissolution but allow oxygen transport, maintaining the ORR activity of the catalyst [
21
,
22
,
23
]. Among these, carbon materials have been extensively studied due to their tunability by doping with N, P, and other nonprecious metals [
7
,
23
,
24
]. Doping significantly changes the electronic structure of carbon materials so that the doped carbon itself can have ORR activity. It has been reported that the encapsulation of the Pt nanoparticle catalyst with N-doped carbon exhibits a synergetic effect in achieving both higher electrochemical activity and stability [
25
,
26
,
27
]. In these studies, the N-doped carbon layer was generally formed on the pre-synthesized Pt nanoparticles via N-containing polymer deposition (e.g., polyaniline) and the subsequent carbonization process. However, few studies looked at the Pd catalyst, even though a protecting layer seems to be more essential for the less noble Pd. Herein, a facile synthesis method of the Pd catalyst encapsulated with N-containing carbon for ORR is demonstrated. We synthesized the catalyst using a one-step procedure where the chemical reduction of Pd precursors is accompanied by the oxidative polymerization of aniline [
28
,
29
]. We previously reported on a one-step method to synthesize the Pt catalyst encapsulated in N-containing carbon layer using Pt-aniline complexes, achieving higher ORR activity and stability than commercial Pt/C [
26
]. A similar strategy was applied to Pd in this study.

0.5 g K
2
PdCl
6
and 0.1 g carbon black (Ketjen black® EC-300J, AkzoNobel, Amsterdam, Netherlands) were mixed in 10 ml aniline solution (aniline hydrochloride, Sigma-Aldrich, St. Louis, Missouri, USA) under Ar purging for 30 min. The mixture was then irradiated by 20 kHz ultrasound at 8 W cm
−2
for 3 hours using a horn ultrasonic generator (Digital Sonifier 450, Branson Ultrasonics, Danbury, CT, USA) at 10 °C. After ultrasound irradiation, the mixture was stored on a shelf overnight to complete the reaction. The mixture was then centrifuged at 10,000 rpm for 30 min and filtered. The filtered material was dried and powdered in a mortar. The prepared powder (Pd−PANI-K) was then pyrolized at 300 °C, 500 °C, 700 °C, and 900 °C in N
2
atmosphere for 2 hours at a heating rate of 30 °C min
−1
. The heat-treated samples were labeled Pd-PANI-K@300 °C, Pd-PANI-K@500 °C, Pd-PANI-K@700 °C, and Pd-PANI-K@900 °C, respectively, according to the heat treatment temperature.

An electrochemical analysis was performed by a potentiostat (Autolab M204, Metrohm Autolab, Utrecht, Netherlands) with a three-electrode electrochemical cell. The counter and reference electrodes were Pt coil and Ag/AgCl (3.5 M KCl) electrodes, respectively. A glassy carbon rotating disk electrode (0.196 cm
2
, Pine Research Instrumentation, Durham, NC, USA) was used as the working electrode. Catalyst loading was performed by pipetting a catalyst slurry onto the working electrode surface. The catalyst slurry was prepared by mixing 10 mg of a prepared sample, 66 μl ionomer (Nafion® 5 wt%, DuPont, Wilmington, DE, USA), and 1 ml isopropyl alcohol (Junsei, Tokyo, Japan) under sonication for 30 min. The commercial Pd/C (20 wt%, Premetek Co., Wilmington, DE, USA) was used as a reference. The catalyst loading was 100 μg
Pd
cm
−2
, and electrochemical characterization of prepared samples was done by cyclic voltammetry (CV) and linear sweep voltammetry (LSV). The CV was conducted in Ar-saturated 0.1 M HClO
4
at a scan rate of 20 mV s
−1
within the potential range between 0.05 V and 1.2 V (vs. reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE)). The LSV for ORR activity evaluation was performed in O
2
-saturated 0.1 M HClO
4
at a scan rate of 5 mV s
−1
. The potential range for the LSV was 0.05 V–1.10 V (vs. RHE), and the rotating speed of the working electrode was 1600 rpm. The stability of the catalysts was tested by repeatedly performing the CV at the same condition. All electrochemical analyses were carried out at 20 °C.

Field emission secondary electron microscope (FE-SEM; JSM-7800F, JEOL, Tokyo, Japan) and high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HR-TEM; Talos F200X, FEI Technai, Hillsboro, OR, USA) were used to observe of surface morphologies. Elemental mapping images were obtained by energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS; Oxford Instruments, Abingdon, UK). The crystalline structures of the synthesized catalysts were characterized using high-resolution X-ray diffractometer (HR-XRD; SmartLab, Rigaku, Tokyo, Japan). The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed with a thermogravimetric analyzer (Scinco, Seoul, Republic of Korea). The chemical states of the catalysts were characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS; PHI 5000 Versa Probe II, ULVAC-PHI Inc., Chigasaki, Kanagawa, Japan).

Figure
1a and b
shows the morphologies of the filtered material (Pd-PANI) from the K
2
PdCl
6
-aniline mixture after ultrasound irradiation. No carbon black was added to the mixture in this case. As shown in the figures, the rod-shaped Pd-PANI is surrounded by a 5-nm-thick polyaniline with Pd nanoparticles approximately 2 nm in size embedded in the structure. During ultrasound irradiation, the aniline monomer released an electron in each polymerization step, reducing Pd ions to Pd atoms simultaneously. The reduced Pd atoms were subsequently aggregated and stabilized in a polyaniline matrix [
28
,
29
]. EDS mapping images (Fig.
1d, e, and f
) show the uniform distribution of N, Cl, and Pd over the structure where N and Cl are elements of aniline and K
2
PdCl
6
, respectively. This indicates that Pd-PANI originates from the Pd precursor and aniline. A similar structure from a Pd-acetate and
o
-methoxyaniline mixture was reported by Mallick et al. [
29
]. The formation of Pd-PANI was also confirmed from the ultraviolet-visible absorption spectrum which shows the absorption peaks associated with π-π
*
transition within benzenoid units and polaron/bipolaron transition of polyaniline located at 292 nm and 400 nm, respectively (Fig. S1). The blue shift of the π-π
*
transition peak from its original position (320 nm) indicates the interaction between Pd nanoparticles and N atoms of polyaniline [
30
,
31
,
32
].

(a) FE-SEM, (b) HR-TEM, (c) high-angle annular dark-field (HAADF) images of Pd-PANI, and elemental mapping images of Pd-PANI for (d) N, (c) Cl, and (f) Pd. The inset in (b) is the magnified image of Pd-PANI

Pd-PANI was also synthesized using carbon black (Pd-PANI-K), which rarely affects the formation of Pd-PANI: rod-shaped Pd-PANIs were uniformly mixed with carbon black in Pd-PANI-K (Fig.
2a
). The synthesized Pd-PANI-K was then heat-treated at 300 °C, 500 °C, 700 °C, and 900 °C for the carbonization of polyaniline. The heat treatment temperatures were selected based on the TGA profile of Pd-PANI. Figure
2
shows the TGA profiles of Pd-PANI, aniline monomer (aniline hydrochloride), and commercial polyaniline (average molecular weight > 15,000, Sigma-Aldrich, St. Louis, Missouri, USA). The aniline monomer decomposed at 170 °C, demonstrating a sharp decrease in weight. In the case of polyaniline, three weight loss steps were observed: water removal (40 °C), low-molecular-weight polyaniline decomposition (270 °C), and high-molecular-weight polyaniline decomposition (600 °C). The weight loss in a wide temperature range in the third step was due to the variation in the molecular weight of polyaniline. Pd-PANI also showed three weight loss steps. The first weight loss (260 °C) can be attributed to low-molecular-weight polyaniline decomposition. The second weight loss, starting at 270 °C, can be attributed to the removal of Cl from the polyaniline matrix, which was also observed in our previous study [
26
]. After the removal of Cl, no further weight loss occurred up to 700 °C, where the third weight loss step was initiated. The origin of the third weight loss step is not clear. However, it was assumed that the decomposition of high-molecular-weight polyaniline causes the third weight loss step, although the temperature range does not exactly match that of commercial polyaniline. The decomposition mechanism of Pd-PANI has not yet been fully understood.
TGA profiles of Pd-PANI, aniline monomer, and commercially available polyaniline

Figure
3
shows TEM images of Pd-PANI-Ks after heat treatment at different temperatures. Heat treatment at temperatures over 300 °C destroyed the rod-shaped Pd-PANI structure completely (Fig.
2a
). The average diameter of Pd nanoparticles, originally embedded in the Pd-PANI structure, increased from 5.6 (± 1.5) nm to 26 (± 22) nm with an increase in the heat treatment temperature due to sintering, as shown in Fig.
2
. However, regardless of the heat treatment temperature, each Pd nanoparticle was encapsulated in a carbon shell of 1–2 nm thickness corresponding to 2 or 3 layers of carbon. The carbon layer originates from the polyaniline decomposition, as reported previously [
26
]. The carbon-coated Pd nanoparticles were uniformly distributed over carbon black after the heat treatment, except for Pd-PANI-K@900 °C. Pd nanoparticles showed a strong aggregation at such a high temperature, leading to a large deviation (± 22 nm) in their size (Fig.
3d
and Fig.
2e
).
HR-TEM images of Pd-PANI-Ks heat-treated at (a) 300 °C, (b) 500 °C, (c) 700 °C, and (d) 900 °C. Insets in TEM images show individual Pd particles covered by carbon layer and their size distribution

Figure
4
shows XRD spectra of heat-treated Pd-PANI-Ks. The diffraction peaks of crystalline polyaniline were usually observed between 20° and 30°, which originated from the highly pronounced oscillation structure of polyaniline [
32
]. However, various kinds of diffraction peaks were detected in the wide range of 2 theta from the as-prepared Pd-PANI-K. This indicates that the synthesized Pd-PANI-K is highly crystalline. Although assigning all the diffraction peaks was not possible due to the lack of information, high crystallinity might have resulted from the ultrasound irradiation and the specific coordination between Pd and aniline [
26
,
32
]. The characteristic peaks of Pd were rarely observed before heat treatment, even though reduced Pd was observed from the TEM images (Fig.
1b
inset). This indicates that the Pd nanoparticles in the as-prepared Pd-PANI-K are close to amorphous, rather than crystalline. After heat treatment at 300 °C, most diffraction peaks observed from the as-prepared Pd-PANI-K were found to be significantly diminished due to the decomposition of polyaniline, while two new peaks appeared at 39.4° and 45.8°. These two peaks then shifted to high angles with the heat treatment temperature to reach the bulk Pd(111) and Pd(200) positions at 40.1° and 46.6°, respectively. The Pd in the as-prepared Pd-PANI-K, which is nearly amorphous due to the incorporation of excess N atoms, started to agglomerate and form crystalline Pd nitrides under heat treatment, exhibiting new diffraction peaks that appeared at lower angles than those of the pure bulk Pd. The incorporation of N into the Pd lattice increased lattice spacing, thereby shifting the diffraction peaks of Pd to lower angles [
33
]. As the heat treatment temperature increased, the agglomeration severity also increased, causing the simultaneous release of N atoms from Pd nitrides. The release of N atoms from the Pd matrix shifted the diffraction peaks to higher angles. At the highest temperature (900 °C), therefore, the characteristic diffraction peaks of Pd(111) and Pd(200) were clearly observed since most N atoms were released from the Pd matrix. The sizes of the Pd nanoparticles calculated by the Scherrer equation were 2.7 nm, 4.3 nm, 17.3 nm, and 18.6 nm for 300 °C, 500 °C, 700 °C, and 900 °C, respectively, which is similar to the values shown in Fig.
3
. The XRD spectra of carbon black and commercial polyaniline are shown in Fig.
3
.
Comparison of XRD patterns of Pd-PANI-Ks before and after the heat treatment at 300 °C, 500 °C, 700 °C, and 900 °C

The change in chemical states of Pd and N in the as-prepared Pd-PANI-K upon heat treatment was also observed by XPS. Figure
5a
shows the XPS spectra of Pd 3d at different heat treatment temperatures. At 300 °C, two Pd states were observed: Pd
4+
and Pd
0
. The two peaks, located at 343.2 eV and 337.9 eV, demonstrate that the oxidation state of Pd was approximately 4+ due to the reaction with N atoms, which is identical to the XPS data of N-rich Pd (PdN
6.7
) as reported by Veith et al. [
33
]. Pd
0
3d
3/2
and Pd
0
3d
5/2
peaks were located at 340.8 eV and 335.5 eV, respectively. These peaks of Pd-PANI-K@300
o
C also shifted by 0.4 eV to the higher binding energies as compared to their original positions in the bulk, which were 340.4 eV for Pd
0
3d
3/2
and 335.1 eV for Pd
0
3d
5/2
. The N atoms incorporated in N-rich Pd or in a carbon shell may interact with Pd and alter the electronic state of Pd
0
. Unfortunately, there is a lack of clarity on the dominant factor. Either way, the positive shift of the Pd core-level binding energy is known to be beneficial to ORR as it accompanies a down shift of the d-band center of Pd [
20
]. At heat treatment temperatures higher than 300 °C, Pd
0
3d core-level doublet peaks were observed, indicating that N atoms from N-rich Pd were released upon heat treatment as also shown in Fig.
4
. The N 1 s spectra show two major peaks located at 400.4 eV and 398.6 eV, as shown in Fig.
5b
. The two N 1 s peaks might be attributed to the presence of pyrrolic N and pyridinic N in a carbon shell. N atoms in Pd-rich and N-rich Pd also showed core-level binding energies around 398 eV and 399 eV–402 eV, respectively [
33
]. Unfortunately, these peaks had high overlap which made it difficult to deconvolute the N 1 s spectra. However, it was assumed that the N atoms in the carbon layer surrounding the Pd nanoparticles will have a larger effect on the N 1 s spectra than those in the Pd matrix. Therefore, the N 1 s spectra was deconvoluted into two peaks, corresponding to pyrrolic N and pyridinic N. The peak intensity of pyridinic N decreased with an increase in the heat treatment temperature. Pyridinic N is also known as an additional active site for ORR, whereas pyrrolic N is inactive for the same [
34
].
XPS spectra of (a) Pd 3d and (b) N 1 s on Pd-PANI-Ks after the heat treatment at 300 °C, 500 °C, 700 °C, and 900 °C

Figure
6
shows the ORR polarization curves of heat-treated Pd-PANI-Ks as compared to commercial Pd/C. The half-wave potentials (
E
1/2
) of Pd-PANI-K@300 °C and Pd-PANI-K@500 °C were 775 mV and 788 mV, respectively, which were positively shifted relative from that of Pd/C (767 mV). This positive shift may be attributed to the presence of pyridinic N in a carbon layer. As shown in Fig.
5b
, the proportion of pyridinic N was relatively high when Pd-PANI-K was heat-treated at 300 °C and 500 °C. The positive shift of XPS Pd
0
3d peak in Pd-PANI-K@300 °C did not significantly affect the ORR activity as compared to Pd-PANI-K@500 °C. The relatively low ORR activity of Pd-PANI-K@700 °C and Pd-PANI-K@900 °C was due to the large Pd particle size and low proportion of pyridinic N in a carbon layer. It should be noted that the curves for the heat-treated Pd-PANI-Ks were obtained after 50 CV cycles, whereas those for Pd/C were obtained without cycling. In the heat-treated Pd-PANI-Ks, the initial ORR activity was poor due to the presence of a thick carbon layer on Pd (Fig.
4
). A carbon layer enhances the stability of the Pd catalyst by protecting Pd from dissolution. However, it also blocks ORR active sites of Pd if the thickness is very high. The consecutive potential cycling leads to slight carbon corrosion, exposing more active sites of Pd [
23
]. In the case of Pd/C, the
E
1/2
was negatively shifted by 247 mV even after 50 CV cycles (Fig.
5a
).

ORR polarization curves of Pd/C and heat-treated Pd-PANI-Ks before the potential cycling. The polarization was performed in O
2
-saturated 0.1 M HClO
4
at a scan rate of 5 mV s
−1

The CV and ORR curves of Pd/C, Pd-PANI-K@300 °C, and Pd-PANI-K@500 °C before and after 300 potential cycles are shown in Fig.
7a, b, and c
, respectively. Both Pd-PANI-K@300 °C and Pd-PANI-K@500 °C demonstrated superior long-term stability as compared to Pd/C, even though the CV was performed in the range of 0.05 V–1.2 V, including the standard reduction potential of Pd (0.915 V). A large Pd dissolution current was observed at 1.0 V, as shown in the inset of Fig.
7a
, whereas it was negligible in the insets of Fig.
7b and c
. These results clearly indicate that a carbon shell in the heat-treated Pd-PANI-Ks protects Pd nanoparticles from dissolution but allows oxygen penetration. A stronger suppression of Pd dissolution (lower Pd dissolution current) was observed in Pd-PANI-K@500 °C as compared to that in Pd-PANI-K@300 °C, which supports the assertion that the carbon shell at 500 °C is more solid than at 300 °C, as shown in the insets of Fig.
7b and c
. The carbon shell robustness of Pd-PANI-K@500 °C can be also confirmed by measuring the electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) of the catalysts. Table
1
summarizes
E
1/2
and ECSA of the catalysts before and after potential cycling. The ECSA values were obtained from the hydrogen adsorption/desorption charge in the potential region between 0.10 V and 0.40 V to minimize contributions from hydrogen absorption by Pd [
19
,
35
,
36
]. The
E
1/2
of Pd-PANI-K@300 °C and Pd-PANI-K@500 °C showed negligible potential loss after cycling. Meanwhile, a drastic potential loss was observed for Pd/C. The ECSA of the commercial Pd/C decreased by 93% after 300 cycles, whereas Pd-PANI-K@300 °C showed 29% decrease in ECSA. Pd-PANI-K@500 °C showed a slight increase in ECSA, which was attributed to slight carbon corrosion during cycling. In terms of stability, Pd-PANI-K@500 °C showed the best performance, although the ECSA of Pd-PANI-K@300 °C was the largest due to the small size of Pd nanoparticles (Fig.
2a
). The lower stability of Pd-PANI-K@300 °C than that of Pd-PANI-K@500 °C could be presumable because the aniline carbonization, which forms a carbon layer, was not completely performed at 300 °C. Even with greater ECSA, the ORR activity of Pd-PANI-K@300 °C was slightly lower than that of Pd-PANI-K@500 °C. This indicates indirectly that the N-rich Pd of Pd-PANI-K@300 °C had a negative influence on the ORR activity. It was also reported that Ni-rich Pd (PdN
6.7
) was less active than metallic Pd in the catalytic oxidation of benzyl alcohol due to lack of active sites [
33
]. Nonetheless, the high stability of the two catalysts clearly indicates that the use of aniline as a source of a carbon layer covering Pd nanoparticles was effective in protecting Pd from dissolution. The CV and ORR curves for all heat-treated Pd-PANI-Ks are shown in Fig.
5
. The catalyst degradation of Pd-PANI-K@300 °C and Pd-PANI-K@500 °C began to be observed from at least 300 cycles. Figure
6
shows TEM images of Pd-PANI-K@300 °C and Pd-PANI-K@500 °C after 500 cycles. After 500 cycles, the average size of Pd particles in Pd-PANI-K@300 °C increased from 2.7 nm to 12.41 nm (4.6 times) and that of Pd-PANI-K@500 °C increased from 4.3 nm to 9.3 nm (2.2 times). This indicates that a severe Pd agglomeration occurred after 500 cycles, regardless of the heat treatment temperature. However, from the fact that the increase in Pd size in Pd-PANI-K@500 °C was smaller than in Pd-PANI-K@300 °C, it was confirmed again that Pd-PANI-K@500 °C is more stable than Pd-PANI-K@300 °C. Although Pd-PANI-K@500 °C did not perform as well as commercial Pt/C (Fig.
5b
), the carbon encapsulation could significantly improve the stability of the Pd catalyst.

ORR polarization curves of (a) Pd/C, (b) Pd-PANI-K@300 °C, and (c) Pd-PANI-K@500 °C before and after the potential cycling. Insets are their CV curves. The ORR polarization was performed in O
2
-saturated 0.1 M HClO
4
at a scan rate of 5 mV s
−1
, whereas CV curves were recorded in Ar-saturated 0.1 M HClO
4
at a scan rate of 20 mV s
−1

figcaption.b:
Table 1 Half-wave potentials (
E
1/2
) and ECSAs of Pd/C and heat-treated Pd-PANI-Ks before and after 300 potential cycles

div.p: In this study, we developed a facile method of synthesizing carbon-encapsulated Pd catalysts for ORR. The catalyst was synthesized via two steps: the oxidative polymerization of aniline with Pd precursors and the subsequent heat treatment. The oxidative polymerization of aniline in the presence of Pd precursors formed rod-shaped polyaniline matrices in which the Pd nanoparticles were embedded. The subsequent heat treatment yielded Pd catalysts that were coated with a ~2-nm-thick carbon layer containing N, which originates from polyaniline. The performance of the catalyst was strongly dependent on the heat treatment temperature. When the Pd catalyst was heat-treated at 300 °C and 500 °C, the durability and activity were better than the commercial Pd/C. The significant improvement in the durability of the catalyst was due to the fact that the carbon layer was protecting the dissolution of Pd.
